definitions.definition: to mention something as a reason or an example, or in order to support what you are saying

examples.text: She **cited examples** of companies the city has helped relocate or expand.
**Citing** unnamed **sources**, the newspaper reports that the two companies are nearing a deal.
There is no reason to doubt the information in the articles **cited above**.
He cited personal reasons for his decision to resign.
The Bank of England has again cited concerns about inflation.
Their method is similar to those used by many **studies cited** in this report.
He cited his heavy workload as the reason for his breakdown.
The most commonly cited reasons for stopping the treatment were side effects.
This is similar to the example cited above.
She cited the case of Leigh v. Gladstone.
One doctor cited the case of a three-year-old dying as a result of extreme obesity.
This album is often cited as an example of a truly great complete album.

definitions.definition: to speak or write the exact words from a book, an author, etc.

examples.text: He **cites** no primary **sources** for his claims.
She cited a passage from the President’s speech.
She is the author most often cited in his work.

definitions.definition: to order somebody to appear in court; to name somebody officially in a legal case

examples.text: He was cited for contempt of court.
She was cited in the divorce proceedings.

definitions.definition: to mention somebody officially or publicly because they deserve special praise

wordOrigin: late Middle English (in sense (3), originally with reference to a court of ecclesiastical law): from Old French citer, from Latin citare, from ciere, cire ‘to call’.
